case_vignette:
A 70-year-old White man presents for evaluation of a recent foot injury. The patient states that he hit his foot at home and noticed blood on the floor; because of a previous injury, he was unable to view his sole. A large (several cm), irregularly shaped plaque is seen on the mid-anterior volar foot. The lesion is brown and black, with central red discoloration and overlying yellow-white scale. The patient reports that the lesion has been present for several months. The patient has a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and a previous injury to the foot. The patient is a nonsmoker and has a family history of cardiovascular disease. The patient's vital signs are within normal limits. The patient's physical examination is notable for a large, irregularly shaped plaque on the mid-anterior volar foot, as described above. The patient's skin is dry and rough, with multiple actinic keratoses on the face and hands. The patient's gait is normal, and he is able to bear weight on the affected foot. The patient's neurological examination is normal. The patient's laboratory results are within normal limits. The patient's radiographic studies are normal. The patient's diagnosis is a plantar wart, which is a benign growth on the foot caused by the human papillomavirus (HPV). The patient is advised to avoid walking barefoot and to use antifungal creams to prevent secondary infection. The patient is also advised to have regular follow-up appointments to monitor the lesion for signs of malignancy.

The patient is a nonsmoker and has a family history of cardiovascular disease. The patient's vital signs are within normal limits. The patient's physical examination is notable for a large, irregularly shaped plaque on the mid-anterior volar foot, as described above

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?

Hi! I recently hit my foot at home and noticed a large, irregularly shaped spot with brown, black, and red discoloration, covered by a yellow-white scaly layer on the mid-front part of my foot. This spot has been present for several months.
Have there been any changes in the size, shape, or color of the spot since you first noticed it?
No, there have been no changes in the size, shape, or color of the spot since I first noticed it.
Do you experience any itching, pain, or bleeding from the spot?
No, I do not experience any itching, pain, or bleeding from the spot.
Do you have any personal or family history of skin cancer or other significant medical conditions?
I have a family history of cardiovascular disease and personally, I have hypertension and hyperlipidemia, but no history of skin cancer.
Have you had similar lesions elsewhere on your body, past or present?
No, I haven't had similar lesions elsewhere on my body, but I do have multiple rough, dry spots on my face and hands.
Final Diagnosis: Actinic Keratosis.
